0: (CNN) A sign memorializing Emmett Till, who was brutally murdered 63 years ago, has been vandalized -- again. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It's the third sign to go up at the site outside Glendora, Mississippi, near where the 14-year-old's body was pulled from the Tallahatchie River in 1955. And it was installed just 35 days before it was pierced with bullets. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The people who put it up might just leave it that way. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Patrick Weems, co-founder of the county-supported Emmett Till Interpretive Center , said the community has ignored Emmett's vicious murder long enough. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "For 50 years, our community lived in silence, and there's those who want to erase history," he told CNN. "We've been through that." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The marker's rough past NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Emmett Till's memorial signs have seen trouble from the start. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Eight years later, its replacement was The first sign went up along the river in 2007, 52 years after Emmett's death. In 2008, it was stolen, Weems said. Nobody ever found it.Eight years later, its replacement was riddled with bullet holes in multiple acts of vandalism, Weems said. That sign now sits in the interpretive center's museum. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR And last month, the third sign was put up near the river. Only 35 days went by before it was shot up. A professor from nearby Delta State University found the sign defaced by bullet holes, Weems said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Whether it was racially motivated or just pure ignorance, it's still unacceptable," he told CNN. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR No one seems to know who's responsible for the incidents. Two spokespeople from the Tallahatchie County Sheriff's Office did not know of any arrests or findings made related to any of the signs. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The second version of the memorial sign in 2016. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR What Weems does know is that the sign is about two miles down a gravel road -- a bit of a trek from town -- and shooting it was no accident. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR To Weems, it's a sign of systemic racism the area has long struggled to combat. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "It's a stark reminder that racism still exists," he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A killing that shook a nation NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It was the summer of 1955 in the Jim Crow South. Emmett, more affectionately known as "Bobo" by the people who loved him, had traveled to Mississippi from Chicago to visit his great-uncle. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Once there the teen was falsely accused of flirting with Carolyn Bryant, a 21-year-old at the time. Bryant and her husband, Roy, owned a grocery store in Money, Mississippi. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Four days went by. Then, in the middle of the night on August 28, 1955, Roy Bryant and his half-brother, J.W. Milam, paid Emmett a visit. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR They rousted him from his bed and ordered him into the bed of a pickup truck. They beat him mercilessly. Then they took his life by shooting him in the head. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR To get rid of Emmett's body, his killers strapped a 75-pound cotton gin to his neck with barbed wire. That way he'd be weighed down when they threw his battered body in the Tallahatchie. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Bryant and Milam went on trial less than a month after Emmett's body was pulled from the river. There were eyewitnesses who saw them. The men admitted they had kidnapped Emmett. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR That evidence wasn't enough. Bryant and Milam were acquitted by an all-white jury. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The grimmest part: a year later, his killers confessed. Double jeopardy laws let them get away with it without facing another trial. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But his death horrified the nation -- Emmett's mother insisted on an open-casket funeral so "all the world" could see what was done to him -- and helped spark the embers of what became a nationwide civil rights movement. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR How the community is moving forward NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Mississippi community's made a lot of progress since then, Weems said, but there's still plenty of work to be done. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Moments like these are defining, he said. There are two options: letting the vandalism divide a community that's already divided by opinions, politics and races. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Or, he said, it can help get things back on track. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "It's difficult to celebrate anything when you know there's so much work to go," he told CNN. "But we still keep coming back to the table." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Part of moving forward, Weems said, involves protecting Emmett's history. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR For one, the National Park Service is considering designating sites related to Till's lynching as national park areas.
